Derek James wrote:

>Ian,
>
>What makes it bloat, and not useful complexification, is a disproportionate
>increase in size without a corresponding increase in fitness.  So I assume
>that you're seeing an increase in size, without a corresponding increase in
>fitness.
>
>If increasing the deletion mutations is having no effect on the rate of
>growth, I'd say there's a problem with your algorithm.
>
>Also, instead of merely increasing the deletion mutation rate, you might try
>decreasing the additive mutation rates.
>
>Derek
>
>  
>

As well as additive mutations, crossover also results in structure being 
copied throughout a population and quite possibly faster than deletion 
mutations can remove them. Also the speciation in standard NEAT causes 
offspring with different structure (either via add or delete mutation) 
to get placed into their own species thus leaving the original species 
with the offspring with the same amount of structure. This occurs if say 
you get a lot of neutral additive mutations - they create new bloated 
species.

It might be worth casting an eye over my phased pruning write-up again, 
as I covered some of this in that.

Colin.
